author: tenacious_seahorse_09647

author: mrabino1
content: are there any estimates on how much the "tip" would be per block if 1559 were implemented today? thx

author: sky.cactus
content: The inclusion fee is expected (assuming rational profit motivated miners) to be around 1 nanoeth per gas for any transaction who isn't competing on ordering (not fighting for first place in the block).

author: sky.cactus
content: The base fee we should expect to be about whatever current gas price in block today is, minus 1 nanoeth.

author: pietjepuk
content:
(continuing conversation starting at https://discordapp.com/channels/595666850260713488/749160974506000444/824396292649910292 )

The EIP-1559 spec implies that the base fee can drop to zero in multiple locations, but it seems we can never drop below `(BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR  - 1)` due to the minimum decrement not being 1 (unlike the increment).

author: sky.cactus
content: Where do you see `base_fee_max_change_denominator - 1` in the spec?

author: jochembrouwer
content: Will voice this here again, it would be very nice if we can finalize the EIP1559 spec and also get consensus tests in ethereum/tests ASAP, otherwise I am not confident in merging any PR related to this EIP. CC EIP champion <@!552133098075193354> can we get consensus tests ASAP?

author: sky.cactus
content: Spec is basically done.  I agree that consensus tests would be valuable.

author: pietjepuk
content: In practice it just can't drop any lower

author: sky.cactus
content:
```py
gas_used_delta = 9000000 - 0
base_fee_per_gas_delta = 1 * 9000000 // 9000000 // 8
expected_base_fee_per_gas = max(1 - 0, 0)
```

author: sky.cactus
content: Is my math correct there?

author: sky.cactus
content: Assuming my math is correct, then I agree with you on the expected behavior and that the test is wrong.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Yes, but my point was that there is e.g. a clipping of the base fee to zero (you made a PR for this iirc), a minimum increment of 1, and some mentions in the EIP of the base fee being able to drop to zero. If it turns out it can't (and it certainly looks that way), then we should
1) change the spec to have a minimum decrement of 1 (to mirror the behavior of the increment), or
2) remove mentions of base fee being able to drop to zero from the EIP

author: sky.cactus
content: I like (2).

author: pietjepuk
content: I like 1 üòâ

author: sky.cactus
content: Where are the mentions you are referring to in (2)?

author: sky.cactus
content: Just the mention in Security Considerations?

author: pietjepuk
content: Yeah, that one. And this as well `expected_base_fee_per_gas = max(parent_base_fee_per_gas - base_fee_per_gas_delta, 0)`

author: sky.cactus
content: I dislike adding additional code that is unnecessary (such as (1)).

author: pietjepuk
content: well, if you want the base fee to be able to drop to zero it's not really unnecessary

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't *want* the base fee to drop to 0.

author: sky.cactus
content: 0 and epsilon are effectively the same for all intents and purposes.

author: sky.cactus
content: We also are fine if it *can* drop to 0.

author: sky.cactus
content: So whichever results in a simpler implementation is desirable IMO.

author: pietjepuk
content: Also, I'm not entirely sure about this (you have to use a `sign` operation), but if you include a minimum decrement of 1 as well, you can merge the three branches into one

author: sky.cactus
content: And by "simpler" that includes "easier to grok/easier to read/harder to get wrong"

author: sky.cactus
content: We explicitly want to avoid signed math.

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, consensus protocol doesn't have any signed math and we didn't want to introduce that here.

author: sky.cactus
content: Signed math means you have to deal with all the different ways various languages deal with signed integers.

author: pietjepuk
content: OK. Anyway, I'm OK with the base fee not being able to drop to zero. But I think it's kind of ugly if you can easily allow it to, and make the code in the branches more similar in the process.

author: sky.cactus
content: I wouldn't strongly oppose `min(parent_base_fee_per_gas + base_fee_per_gas_delta, 1)`.  I just don't think it will help anything.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I'm talking about changing
`base_fee_per_gas_delta = parent_base_fee_per_gas * gas_used_delta // parent_gas_target // BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR`
to 
`base_fee_per_gas_delta = max(parent_base_fee_per_gas * gas_used_delta // parent_gas_target // BASE_FEE_MAX_CHANGE_DENOMINATOR, 1)`

i.e. change it to the exact same line of code that is already there in the "elif" branch. To me that would make it "easier to grok/easier to read/harder to get wrong".

author: sky.cactus
content: I can get on board with that I guess.

author: mrabino1
content: <@301186049323958275> re the inclusion fee for a moment and expected amounts. you outlined that 1 nanoeth for transactions that are not competing... for the standard transaction, i see you point. for ones that are oracles or arb transactions i suspect it won't be 1. real question i suppose is out of the current transactions in a given day, what % do we think are willing to pay that inclusion fee? i suspect it will take months for folks to get comfortable in not having to "bid up" the fees to be included.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the question you want to ask is, "what percentage of transactions engage in gas price auctions?"?

author: mrabino1
content: that plus given how cheap 1 nanoeth is i suspect many will add the fee $0.01 just to outbid those that exclude it ...

author: sky.cactus
content: The answer is "it is complicated to find out, though you can make reasonable educated guesses by looking at all transactions in the block and plucking outliers.

author: mrabino1
content: where i am headed with this is to compute a reasonably educated approximation of what increase PoS validators could expect (and then i am modeling the expected behavior) ...

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the easiest step would be to walk block history and divide the block up into transactions with similar gas price, and then outliers.

author: sky.cactus
content: The outliers would have paid the same regardless of base fee, so you just subtract the minimum price found in the block from them and everything else would go to the block producer.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can take it a step further by looking at other forms of miner payment like transferring ETH directly to block.coinbase.  This has started showing up in newer blocks.

author: mrabino1
content:
y y ... napkin math... eth2 validators make around $6 for proposing a block (at present prices).... if we assumed a $0.01 inclusion fee on half of the transactions and with ~ 200 transactions per block, then post merge, validators (again at present eth prices) would make $1 extra per block.   that $0.01 is larger than the 1 nanoeth..... of course it also depends on how much folk bid to get into a transaction and maybe $0.01 is insanely low..
at the end of the day it will also depend on L2 adoption as well.  regardless it will be a welcome incentive to help bring on more validators if that inclusion fee is materially larger than the current validator reward. good news is we will have months of post-1559 transaction history to help would-be validators make a decision

author: jgm
content: Bear in mind that the block proposal fee itself is currently broken, and is 1/4 what it should be.  I'm not sure the delta from $24 to $25 is going to bring in hoards of new stakers, though.

author: sky.cactus
content: ü§î I think validators have very different costs for block production than miners.  IIRC, uncle risks are significantly different for validators vs miners which means that `1 nanoeth` may be notably lower for validators (or higher!).

author: jgm
content:
Although... unless I'm mucking up my math somewhere we have a 12.5x10^6 block gas limit and a 10^-9 ETH/gas tip, which is 0.0125 ETH, or around $20 at current prices.

(Or are we not considering it in terms of ETH/gas?)

author: jgm
content: (It's also a little different, because the block proposal "reward" in ETH2 is really a claw-back, as you're paying a proportion of your attestations rewards to other block proposers to include them and this is how you make it back.)

author: mrabino1
content: <@144468805697929216> yeah I am the one concerned I messed up the math.. üòâ   more than anything my comment about incentivizing validators is purely to compute an approx additiong yield compared to what is earned today without the inclusion fee.

author: timbeiko
content: Agreed. Abdel said in the other channel he can get to it when the implementation is done. ~~Will see if anyone else has the bandwidth. If someone does, and funding is the blocker, please LMK and we can make it happen üôÇ~~ Someone else on Besu may have the bandwidth. Will update soon üëç

author: timbeiko
content:
On a separate note, with the price appreciation of ETH, we still have a decent amount of funds in the 1559 multisig, even with a few big expenses coming up. I think I'd like to put together a RFP for "1559 tooling" across the ecosystem. Ideally, having some libraries/tools that make it easy for people to integrate and take advantage of 1559. 

I'm not sure what the best "level of abstraction" is here: we obviously don't have enough funds to pay, say, every wallet provider, to implement 1559. OTOH, we do have enough (50-100k) to pay a handful of teams to build tooling that will make it easier for them and others to do so. 

<@!388751025789468672> <@!135612611923279872> (and others) are there specific things that are missing that would make your life easier? Obviously, having full support at the client level is already part of the plan.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think `ethers.js` is the most used dapp library.  Probably a good target for "bang per buck" in terms of reaching many users.  I think they are already working on integration.
